articles.headline: Lawmakers Are Warned That Russia Is Meddling to Re-elect Trump
articles.snippet: A classified briefing to House members is said to have angered the president, who complained that Democrats would “weaponize” the disclosure.
articles.abstract: A classified briefing to House members is said to have angered the president, who complained that Democrats would “weaponize” the disclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials warned House lawmakers last week that Russia was interfering in the 2020 campaign to try to get President Trump re-elected, five people familiar with the matter said, a disclosure to Congress that angered Mr. Trump, who complained that Democrats would use it against him.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Julian E. Barnes, Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: How Bloomberg Bungled a Debate That He Had Been Prepped For
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg’s campaign advisers had anticipated tough debate questions on stop-and-frisk and nondisclosure agreements. The former mayor’s performance left his team rattled.
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg’s campaign advisers had anticipated tough debate questions on stop-and-frisk and nondisclosure agreements. The former mayor’s performance left his team rattled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg had put in the hours, his people said — holding mock debate sessions with top aides and meeting at length to prepare in New York and Palm Springs, Calif.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Alexander Burns and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: The Liberal Economists Behind the Wealth Tax Debate
articles.snippet: Gabriel Zucman and Emmanuel Saez have crashed the Democratic primary with their idea — and angered some economists.
articles.abstract: Gabriel Zucman and Emmanuel Saez have crashed the Democratic primary with their idea — and angered some economists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — One of the most liberal policy proposals animating the Democratic presidential primaries is the handiwork of two French economists who are not formally advising any campaign and have barely met the candidates running for the White House.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: A Billion-Dollar Scandal Turns the ‘King of Manuscripts’ Into the ‘Madoff of France’
articles.snippet: Accused of orchestrating a literary Ponzi scheme, Gérard Lhéritier prepares his defense as his breathtaking collection is auctioned off.
articles.abstract: Accused of orchestrating a literary Ponzi scheme, Gérard Lhéritier prepares his defense as his breathtaking collection is auctioned off.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — A letter from Frida Kahlo, signed and twice kissed with red lipstick, fetched just over $8,800. A page of scribbled calculations by Isaac Newton sold for about $21,000. A 1953 handwritten speech by John F. Kennedy took in $10,000.

articles.headline: ‘Politics of Hate’ Takes a Toll in Germany Well Beyond Immigrants
articles.snippet: As the far-right gains traction, harassment and intimidation of local officials are growing, threatening democracy at the grass roots.
articles.abstract: As the far-right gains traction, harassment and intimidation of local officials are growing, threatening democracy at the grass roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLOGNE, Germany — The last time Henriette Reker ran for mayor, she was nearly killed.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
